botanical_details.genus: Begonia can be annuals, evergreen or deciduous perennials or shrubs, with fibrous, tuberous or rhizomatous roots and usually asymmetrical leaves, often strikingly patterned, and small or large flowers, both male and female in the same cluster

how_to_grow.cultivation: Plant tubers indoors in spring in light, well-drained, neutral compost. May be grown permanently in pots or hanging baskets under glass in bright light shaded from direct sun. Otherwise move containers outdoors into a sunny or semi-shaded position when all risk of frost is past. Dry off tubers in winter and store frost free. See Begonias: outdoors
how_to_grow.propagation: Root basal or stem-tip softwood cuttings in spring or summer
how_to_grow.pruning: Deadhead to prolong flowering. Remove old stems and foliage as plant dies back for the winter
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to mealybugs, caterpillars, glasshouse red spider mite, thrips, vine weevils and aphids
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to powdery mildews and stem-rot
